conversation.content:
They're actually doing it. I mean, the whole industry is—is actually adopting my protocols. [gasp softly] Five years of basically everyone telling me I was overthinking patient flow, and now suddenly, um, they're calling it "the gold standard." Like, okay, I get the email yesterday from the consortium, right? And it's just sitting there: [very excited] "Unanimous approval for industry-wide implementation." 

I keep reading it over and over because, honestly, what if I misunderstood? [nervous laugh] But no, it's—it's real. The thing is, uh, I never meant for this to be some revolutionary thing, you know? [warm] I just wanted our clinic to run better, wanted patients to actually feel heard during intake. 

And now, [anxious] oh God, what if there's something I missed? Like, what if it doesn't scale properly and then everyone's looking at me like—[pause] No. No, I tested everything. The pilots in Boston, er, Seattle, they all worked. [confidently] These protocols work because they're simple. They're human.

[sigh] My mom's going to flip when I tell her. She always said I was too detail-oriented for my own good, but look—[chuckle] apparently the whole healthcare industry needed someone who color-codes their grocery lists. [very quietly] We're really doing this.
